Peace remains elusive between Armenia and Azerbaijan
subhead: After more than three decades of conflict, a peace agreement between the two countries was announced in March. But Baku, currently in a position of strength, hesitates to sign. Near the border, Armenians, harboring no illusions, are torn between fears of a new offensive and a sense of defeat.
byline: By Faustine Vincent (Kirants and Yerevan, special correspondent)

title: US attorney general advances investigation into the origins of the Trump-Russia probe

byline: By Carole Dieterich (Dhaka, Bangladesh, special correspondent)

title: Magda Gegenava, chef: 'I became familiar with street food and adapted my recipes so they could be eaten on the go'
subhead: 'Refuge Recipes' (3/6). This summer, chefs from Refugee Food, a group celebrating its 10th anniversary, are sharing the dish that best defines them. Gegenava is a self-taught chef from Georgia who owns two Paris restaurants, where her khinkalis – plump, juicy dumplings – have become the signature dish.

title: In Brazil, pressure from the Trump administration is galvanizing Jair Bolsonaro's supporters
subhead: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets in several Brazilian cities on Sunday to protest the charges leveled against the former president, who faces up to 40 years in prison for an attempted coup d'état following his electoral defeat in 2022.
byline: By Anne-Dominique Correa (Rio de Janeiro, correspondent)

title: AI is sowing discord in the world of fanfiction
subhead: Fanfiction authors often regard the emergence of AI-generated stories with suspicion, and the technology is shaking up the values within fan communities.

title: Sydney Sweeney's American Eagle ad sparks controversy online and pleases Donald Trump
subhead: With a slogan playing on the ambiguity between 'genes' and 'jeans' − 'Sydney Sweeney has great jeans' − the actress has sparked controversy. Some have accused her of promoting eugenics, while President Donald Trump has come to American Eagle's defense, triggering a surge in its stock price.
byline: By Arnaud Leparmentier (New York (United States) correspondent)

Mariia Nazarenko's first days in France after fleeing Ukraine: 'In Kyiv, I was a university professor. Today, I am a refugee searching for toothpaste'
subhead: On February 21, 2022, Nazarenko left Ukraine, thinking it was just for a weekend. The next day, Russia invaded her country. A few days later, she found herself in Lyon. Now 40 years old, she lives in Paris.

title: Three erotic experiences inspired by boredom
subhead: Maïa Mazaurette is on a mission to spice up your steamy summer nights. This week, she suggests doing absolutely nothing – except letting your thoughts wander, caressing yourself for a long time and questioning your certainties.

title: Child-free weddings: 'I would rather she not come at all than have to accept everyone's children'
